snippet: For most of New York City, two companies, Time Warner and Verizon, provide broadband access at an annual cost of close to $1,000 per home. But for many houses, that means no access at all.
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column; broadband access has an annual cost of close to $1,000 per home in New York City, leaving about 2.9 million people in digital dark; city's libraries provide free access within their facilities, but will now try lending people a small box that provides free wireless Internet service for up to five users at a time.
lead_paragraph: For most of New York City, two companies, Time Warner and Verizon, provide broadband access at an annual cost of close to $1,000 per home. But for many houses, that means no access at all.

headline.main: For Those in the Digital Dark, Enlightenment Is Borrowed From the Library
headline.print_headline: For Those in Digital Dark, Enlightenment Is Borrowed From the Library
